What questions? There isn’t a universally agreed upon definition for “blockchain.” Bitcoin’s blockchain, THE BLOCKCHAIN, uses a “hash tree” which you seemed to think was a disqualifier. It’s not. And how other people use their crypto isn’t any of our business. Banks included.
A nicer reply is: Ripple's ledger headers are like Bitcoin's block headers, both chain & incorporate txns by hash.

When people (unsuccessfully) attempt to be clever by claiming that Ripple isn't a blockchain, this is my standard snarky reply: Ripple has superior ledger data structures and there is a good argument to be made that calling it a mere blockchain is belittling and minimizing.

What on earth are you reading? Lol. Hash trees are Merkle trees, which both Bitcoin and Ripple use (and by Ripple I mean the XRPL). People can use $ XRP for whatever they want. Ripple is positioning it as on-demand liquidity. Market makers provide liquidity. Banks provide volume.

Bitcoin on-chain is a bit like a single shared hub and lightning is a bit like switched networks (switches, routers, segments). Other than performance and scalability another benefit of switches is people can't as easily eavesdrop on everything compared with hubs, which broadcast

Let me make it explicit: Roll your own crypto. Roll your own consensus protocol. Roll your own database. That's how we get progress. But make sure you understand the history, subtleties and pitfalls.

The subtlety of the tweet is lost on some people with "fragile egos," but the tweet says the opposite of "don't roll your own crypto." If people did that, we'd have no crypto. I'm a builder and very much a fan of questioning everything and building better software.

If you're smart, you roll your own crypto or consensus protocol. How hard could it be? If you're very smart, you will know that that's a bad idea. This stuff is subtle and you've seen plenty of failures. If you're very very smart, you wrap around.
